analyzed: dhamma paccanīya anuloma duka tika paṭṭhāna pāḷi
translated: The reverse order of the law of conditionality, the triplets in the Paṭṭhāna,

original: 21.21. Hetuduka, Vitakkattika🔽Nahetuṁ nasavitakkasavicāraṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca hetu savitakkasavicāro dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā tīṇi …pe… avigate tīṇi.🔽Nahetuṁ naavitakkavicāramattaṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca hetu avitakkavicāramatto dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā tīṇi …pe… avigate tīṇi.
analyzed: hetu duka vitakka ttika  na hetum na sa vitakka sa vicāram dhammam paṭicca hetu sa vitakka sa vicāraḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā tīṇi pe avigate tīṇi  na hetum na avitakka vicāra mattam dhammam paṭicca hetu avitakka vicāra mattaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā tīṇi pe avigate tīṇi
translated: The section on causes, the section on applied thought🔽With non-cause as condition, a non-cause that is accompanied by applied thought and sustained thought arises, a condition being fulfilled. (In brief.) With regard to cause, there are three. … With regard to non-cognizance, there are three. … With regard to the unconditioned, there are three.🔽With non-cause as condition, a non-cause that is without applied thought and with sustained thought only arises, a condition being fulfilled. (In brief.) With regard to cause, there are three. … With regard to non-cognizance, there are three. … With regard to the unconditioned, there are three.

original: Nahetuṁ naavitakkaavicāraṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca nahetu avitakkaavicāro dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā tīṇi, adhipatiyā tīṇi …pe… avigate tīṇi.
analyzed: na hetum na avitakka avicāram dhammam paṭicca na hetu avitakka avicāraḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā tīṇi adhipatiyā tīṇi pe avigate tīṇi
translated: With non-cause as condition, a non-cause that is without applied thought and without sustained thought arises, a condition being fulfilled. (In brief.) With regard to cause, there are three. … With regard to predominance, there are three. … With regard to the unconditioned, there are three.
